**Chapter Twenty-Three of the *Gōngdé Pǐn* (功德品) – Continuation:**

If one seeks descendants, and reverently upholds and recites this scripture as the law prescribes, the Celestial Sovereign commands the *Tiāncháo* (天曹), who then inspect the *Dānjí* (丹籍) of the Nine Ranks. Among the *sìguǒ xiānrén* (四果仙人), when fate and destiny align, they descend and incarnate to become their child—endowed with eloquence, wisdom, and noble status among mortals.

The efficacy of this scripture is not merely to subdue malevolent forces. If one, afflicted by childlessness, seeks descendants and upholds this scripture with reverence as prescribed, the Celestial Sovereign commands the *Tiāncháo* to examine the *Dānshū Xiānjí* (丹书仙籍). Among the Nine Ranks, the *sìguǒ xiānrén* (四果仙人), when their cosmic cycles and numerical destinies converge, descend and incarnate to become their child.

The child born to one who recites this scripture for descendants will be gifted with eloquence, wisdom, and intelligence, attaining noble status among humanity.

*"Qí"* (祈) means to pray and supplicate the gods in seeking.

Sometimes, others pray for one; other times, one seeks for oneself. Whether one has descendants or not depends on Heaven’s decree—if it cannot be sought, it cannot be sought. Of the three gravest offenses against filial piety, childlessness is the greatest. One must seek descendants, for all who possess *xuèqì* (血气) are capable of procreation.

Perhaps one has exhausted *yīndé* (阴德) or incurred Heaven’s wrath; perhaps one’s *yáng* (阳) and *yīn* (阴) are misaligned, or one’s fate clashes with solitude; perhaps the fetus is weak or one harms oneself in anger, resulting in childlessness.

Yet human resolve can reverse Heaven’s decree—through utmost sincerity and divine resonance, none will remain childless. Thus, descendants can be sought.

*"Sìxī"* (嗣息) means *"sì"* (嗣, to continue) and *"xī"* (息, breath). Some say *"sì"* means to bind, as in binding the ancestral line like a continuous thread. Others say *"sì"* means to govern, overseeing the transmission of family lineage, as recorded in ancestral tablets. *"Xī"* (息) refers to children who continue the ancestral line, like the unceasing inhalation and exhalation of breath.

Moreover, the true breath is the root of life and death—if breath ceases, *qì* (气) vanishes. Having descendants ensures the continuity of sacrifices, hence *"xī"* (息). *"Tàidǐ xī"* (太抵息) refers to the mind itself. With descendants, all concerns are fulfilled, and the mind finds rest—thus it is called *"xī"* (息).

The sages of the Three Teachings all had descendants. How can one not recognize the weight of progeny?

To uphold this scripture with reverence is to revere the scripture itself. Some say one must personally revere it—which is incorrect. The *Tiāncháo* are those who create destinies and oversee the *Xiānjí* (仙籍). The Nine Ranks consist of the upper three *shèng* (乘), the middle three, and the lower three—totaling nine.

The *Shìjìng* (释经) states: *"The Nine-Ranked Lotus is the parent."* The Buddha, Bodhisattvas, *Yuánjué* (圆觉), *Shèngwén* (声闻), and *Āluóhàn* (阿罗汉), as well as those in the four *zhān* (禅) stages, also belong to the Nine Ranks.

The *sìguǒ xiānrén* (四果仙人)—*Xūduōhàn* (须陀洹), *Sītuǒhán* (斯陀含), *Āluóhàn* (阿罗汉), and *Ānàhàn* (阿那含)—descend and incarnate. For the Daoist or Buddhist to take human form is considered descending to the mortal realm, hence *"jiàngdié xiàshēng"* (降谪下生).

*"Cái"* (才) refers to extraordinary talents; *"biàn"* (辩) refers to unparalleled eloquence.

The light shines without failing.
The wisdom awakens without obstruction.

Among mortals, the most honored are not necessarily those who become rulers, ministers, or teachers—
but those who embody **virtue** and the **Way**, perfecting themselves as exemplary sons.
No greater honor than the **Way**,
No greater nobility than **virtue**.
Even the Son of Heaven cannot make them his subject,
Nor can the feudal lords make them their friend.
They assist in governance, nurture the people,
And aid in the completion of all things.
Across countless generations, they are revered,
And across the Three Realms, they are held in esteem.
Thus, they are the most honored among mortals.

If one reveres this **sutra** as law,
Reciting it for oneself or seeking descendants through it,
Though its effects are manifest, one cannot reckon the days—
Only by truly honoring the **sutra**,
Confessing faults with sincerity,
And remaining steadfast from beginning to end,
As though gazing upon the Jade Emperor,
With utmost reverence for this sacred **dharma**,
Will divine efficacy and spiritual power unfold unseen,
Turning fate and altering destiny—
Descendants will naturally arise.

Even mortal heroes gain offspring through merit.
Those who truly believe in the **sutra** and turn the **Dharma Wheel**,
As the functional pillars of heaven and earth,
How could their descendants not prosper?
If one reveres this **sutra** yet fails to secure descendants,
It must be that their sincerity is insufficient,
Or they have not followed the **sutra** from start to finish.

Let all mortals take heed and verify the **sutra’s** divine efficacy.

**Functional Merit Chapter (Continuation, Twenty-Fourth Section):**
If a woman in her critical month of childbirth
Recites this true **sutra** according to the law,
She will give birth safely, mother and child both unharmed,
And bear children of fortune and **virtue**, beloved and respected by all.

The **sutra’s** divine power does more than merely ensure descendants.
If a woman in her critical month of childbirth
Recites this true **sutra** according to the law,
She will deliver swiftly and safely,
Mother and child both unscathed,
And bear children of auspicious fortune and **virtue**, beloved and honored by all.

Once a woman is married into her husband’s family, she is called a **wife**.
The "critical month" refers to the time of childbirth,
When life and death hang in the balance—
Thus, it is called "facing peril."
Reciting the true **sutra** according to the law:
Whether before birth, when she herself observes a pure fast and recites the **sutra**,
Or during birth, when others recite it for her,
She will deliver safely,
With no complications at the hour of birth,
The child born without harm to mother or child,
Both emerging smoothly and in good health—
A benefit to both.

**Fortune** refers to those of wealth, nobility, longevity, and auspicious appearance.
**Virtue** refers to the saintly, loyal, filial, and kind—those of moral excellence.
**Children**, whether male or female, bear **fortune** and **virtue**.
**Beloved and respected** means they are approachable yet not familiar,
Near yet not to be trifled with—
All draw near to them, praise them, and envy them.
This is called **love**.
Yet, when seen from afar, reverence arises;
When approached, laziness fades;
Without words, trust is given;
Without movement, respect is shown.
This is called **respect**.

**Clarification:**
It is fitting for a man to be beloved and respected.
But how can a woman be so?
If her **fortune** is complete and her conduct virtuous,
If she does not weep or jest,
If she is dignified, speaks little,
Moves seldom, and does not laugh,
If she is mature beyond her years,
Grave yet pure in adulthood,
And unchanging until death—
All will love her as kin,
Respect her as elders.
This love is without familiarity;
They envy her **fortune** and **virtue**—
A rarity in the world.

**Verification:**
Mother and child both safe.

The *Shijing*’s chapter *"Shēngmín"* praises Jiāng Yù in giving birth to Hòuxī, saying:
*"The firstborn was born like a strike—no calamity, no harm."*
Jiāng Yù possessed **virtue**, so her firstborn emerged as easily as a lamb—unharmed, with mother and child both at peace.
The *Exegesis* states: *"Mother and child parted early."*
The *Dao Scriptures* declare: *"At childbirth, there is joy; seated on grass, there is no peril."*
The merit of reciting the *Scriptures* responds like an echo.

Now, the *Huángjīng* spreads throughout the world, and many recite it.
Yet women in childbirth may suffer:
Some deliver prematurely before their time,
Some face calamity or peril,
Some encounter ghostly births or omens,
Some endure misfortune or familial strife—
Though many achieve mother and child’s safety, few attain both fully;
Some suffer dual harm as well.

Some say reciting the *Scriptures* may bring no benefit,
Yet the True Law is rare to encounter.
Many do not revere this *Scripture* or know its blessings;
Some hear its name but do not honor it;
Some pay hollow respect without recitation,
Some recite but begin with fervor and end in neglect;
Some omit or confuse passages,
Some recite carelessly, mispronouncing words, distorting phrases,
Misinterpreting meaning—
Though they may offer repentance, they fail to gain the full merit of the *Scripture*.
All these are self-deception, failing to meet the *Scripture*’s power,
Thus concluding that recitation is fruitless—
This is blasphemy against the Law.

Alas, the True Law must be upheld,
And filial piety is hard to repay.
Rescuing suffering, benefiting life—
This is the urgent duty of those who seek the *Way*.
If we teach the world to revere and recite this *Scripture*,
Then mothers and children will be at peace,
Childbirth perils will be averted,
And virtuous sons and daughters will be born—
All will bear marks of **fortune** and **virtue**,
And the True *Dao* will endure forever.
The merit is boundless.

Let those who study the *Scripture* take heed.

**Continuation of Chapter Twenty-Five: The Merit of Virtue**

If one seeks to attain office and advance in rank,
to secure noble titles and abundant stipends,
to be honored by the sovereign—
if one recites and upholds this *True Scripture* in accordance with its precepts,
then one shall be granted promotions in duty,
one’s descendants shall prosper in honor and rank,
and this lineage shall endure through the ages.

The benefits of the *Jade Scripture* extend far beyond mere prosperity in childbirth!
If one seeks to attain office and advance in rank,
to secure noble titles and abundant stipends,
to be honored by the sovereign—
if one recites and upholds this *True Scripture* in accordance with its precepts,
then one shall be entrusted with official duties,
ascend in rank and station,
and one’s descendants shall prosper in honor and rank,
enduring through the ages without cessation.

**Seeking Office:**
Even without office, one may obtain it.
**Advancement in Rank:**
*Advancement* means promotion.
If one’s station is humble, one seeks to rise to higher office and noble duty.
**Titles:**
Titles are conferred upon officials.
**Stipends:**
Stipends are the remuneration given.
**Abundant and Auspicious:**
*Heng* signifies prosperity, ease, and joy—auspicious and beneficial.
**Fulfillment:**
*Da* means to achieve one’s desires, to succeed in one’s aspirations.
**Honored by the Sovereign:**
To be distinguished is called *noble*; titles and stipends are abundant, and one gains the sovereign’s favor, administering affairs and receiving the ruler’s recognition.
The harmony between ruler and subject has always been rare.
To be noble and honored by the sovereign means the subject’s rank is not in vain—this is true fulfillment.
*Alternatively:* To be favored by a wise and enlightened ruler.

*This Scripture* is not redundant; its phrasing is deliberate.

**Official Duties:**
*Job* refers to the responsibilities of office, each with its designated tasks.
*Matter* refers to governance.
**Promotion:**
To be reassigned to a better post or relieved of trivial duties to assume a position of importance.
**Descendants’ Honor and Rank:**
Some inherit office and stipends through generations,
or receive patronage for their children and grandchildren,
enjoying wealth, security, and prestige,
illuminating ancestors and benefiting posterity—
both honored and prosperous, enduring through the ages.
Though not equal to the heavens and earth in permanence,
they endure eternally, blessing future generations,
with grace extending unbroken.
Even across many generations, this is considered enduring.

As with **Confucius the Sage’s** supreme virtue,
or the **Celestial Master’s** divine transformations,
his descendants received imperial appointments through the ages—
this is true, unbroken honor and rank.

**Titles and stipends** originate from the imperial court’s official appointments.
If they cannot be obtained through merit,
one may follow established qualifications for advancement.
If advancement is unattainable through merit,
how much more so must one study diligently—
scholars must master texts, warriors must know warfare.
Learning and achievements cannot be borrowed;
how then can one seek advancement?

Officials are appointed for their virtue,
and stipends are granted to nourish the worthy.
Those of great virtue must attain their rightful position and name.
If one upholds this *True Scripture* in accordance with its precepts,
recites its sacred words,
and follows the Sage’s teachings,
one’s heart aligns with the heavens,
and one’s actions harmonize with the *Way*—
this is the mark of a truly virtuous person.

Some are praised in speech,
others commended in deed;
without titles, they are granted offices,
without rank, they receive stipends,
or their existing offices are elevated—
this is the natural course of employing the worthy.

By virtue, one attracts the worthy.
If they refuse such honors—
as **Broad Achievement**, **Yin Shou**, **Chao You**, or **Yan Guang**—
whether as imperial preceptors or honored guests of the state,
how can it be said that the virtuous cannot attain titles and stipends?
As with **Han’s Zhuge Liang**,
or **Jin-Tang’s Jingyang, Li Bei, and Hai Dan**,
all were men of the *Way* who held office.

The *Scripture* speaks of seeking office—
what more need be said?

**Heavenly Titles** are noble indeed,
and they belong to us inherently.
Ascending beyond the mundane to sainthood,
advancing in virtue step by step,
manifesting divine transformations to attain immortality—
this is unbroken through kalpas.

The *Dao De Jing* says:
*"To die yet not perish."*
The *Transmissions of the Immortals* declare:
*"A child is born, and the child bears grandchildren."*

The *Way* is exalted, virtue is noble,
and the transmissions of the immortals are boundless.
If one does not covet worldly fame or transient gain,
but cultivates the **Heavenly Title’s** true nobility,
transcending the ordinary to approach sainthood,
rising above the dust to attain immortality—
enduring forever without end,
this is truly to uphold the *True Scripture* in accordance with its precepts.

**Continuation of Chapter Twenty-Six: The Merit of Wealth**

If one desires to amass abundant wealth,
and upholds this *True Scripture* in accordance with its precepts,
then treasures shall overflow,
clothing and food shall come naturally,
and blessings shall flow to descendants,
passing to future generations.

The benefits of this *Scripture* extend far beyond fulfilling worldly ambitions for office!
If one desires abundant wealth for one’s family,
and upholds this *True Scripture* in accordance with its precepts,
then riches, treasures, and precious curiosities shall fill to overflowing,
clothing and food shall be plentiful and refined,
naturally abundant without effort,
with blessings extending to descendants,
passing to future generations.

**Wealth:**
*Resource*—what one’s family requires.
*Alternatively:* That which one relies upon, benefiting all.
Same as *capital*.
**Treasures:**
*Wealth*—the wealth one possesses.
*Also:* Wealth as a resource.
**Abundant:**
*Yin*—fullness, completeness.
**Rich:**
When a household’s prosperity reaches its peak,
and resources are fully sufficient.
**Uphold:**
*Delight in reverence* is *uphold*;
to guard, observe, and recite.
**Treasures:**
*Wealth*—the *wealth* of goods.
*Precious*—jade, gold, silver, gems, rare curiosities,
ornaments, silks, and treasures of extraordinary value.
**Overflowing:**
*Chong*—fully sufficient.
*Yi*—abundantly full.
**Clothing and food naturally:**
Without toil, naturally abundant.
**Blessings flow to descendants:**
*Reg* signifies auspiciousness.
Grace extends far, blessing generation after generation—
thus, *blessings flow to descendants*.
**Passing to future generations:**
Not limited to one’s own children,
but transmitted through the ages,
with later generations eternally enjoying peace and honor.

**Resolving Doubts:**
**Confucius** said:
*"Wealth, if it can be sought, even a lowly driver I would serve."*
If it cannot be sought, then follow what one loves.
He strongly states that wealth is not to be pursued—
yet here it is said that if one seeks abundance by upholding this *Scripture* in accordance with its precepts,
one shall attain prosperity and blessings for descendants.
This suggests that wealth *can* be sought.

**Zi Xia** said:
*"The Master heard: Wealth and nobility are decreed by Heaven."*
Though wealth is desirable, fate governs it,
and Heaven truly holds dominion—
how then can it be sought?
Yet though wealth is subject to fate,
the ancient scholars said:
*"Wealth and nobility are the rewards for virtue’s culmination,
a repayment for merit."*

If one upholds and recites this *Scripture* in accordance with its precepts,
speaking the words of Heaven with reverence as though addressing the August Sky,
this is how virtue earns its blessings.

「The *Classics* say: *"Joy belongs to the virtuous gentleman,
blessings follow those who tread the peaceful Way."*
This is what is meant.

Some say: *"Great Yu was a sage,
who drank little and ate plainly,
wore coarse garments and lived in humble dwellings,
yet found sweetness only in simplicity and restraint."*
The Daoist teachings state: *"To learn the Dao, one must embrace poverty to the marrow of the bones."*
This suggests that reciting the *Scripture* can bring wealth—
a claim that may entice those who crave prosperity.

Yu’s own frugality was the heart of a sage who did not hoard virtue for himself.
The Daoists’ pursuit of poverty was to free the mind from worldly burdens.
Though wealth *can* be sought and obtained,
this is the intended effect of upholding the *Scripture*.

The *Buddha’s Scriptures* say: *"All that one seeks with sincere intent
shall be fulfilled and satisfied."*
Both teachings open vast pathways of expedience—
boundless blessings and benefits,
where requests are answered and wishes fulfilled.
If one doubts, hesitates, or falters—
beginning with diligence yet ending in neglect—
if one’s heart is not upright,
lacks steadfast faith, or is not utterly sincere,
then even seeking shall yield no result.
Let those who observe the *Scripture* understand this well.

Consider: all things are inherently complete within me.
There are those who are naturally wealthy without effort.
Yet why do people chase after fame and gain,
compete in superficial luxuries,
indulge in passions and desires,
and mistake falsehood for truth?

The poor suffer in distress,
yet cannot uphold the Great Way,
nor recite the true *Scriptures*.
The rich indulge in extravagance,
yet cannot abandon worldly wisdom and profit
to follow the teachings of the Law,
willing to age and die in their folly,
losing the wealth they were born with.

Laozi said: *"Gold and jade fill the hall,
yet none can guard them;
wealth and rank bring arrogance,
and one invites ruin upon oneself."*
This warns against pursuing externals while neglecting the inner self.

Now it is said that reciting the *Scripture* can bring wealth—
to urge people to abandon their superficial pursuit of riches
and instead honor the *Scripture*.
Ah, truly, reciting the *Scripture* has its effect.
If one lacks sincerity and reverence,
one may only invite transgression.
Let those who observe the *Scripture* be cautious.

**Chapter 27 of *The Merits and Virtues* (continued):**
If one is afflicted by malevolent stars,
suffering hardship in life and death,
and yet recites this *Scripture* in accordance with its precepts,
then these malevolent stars shall retreat,
bringing forth auspicious fortune instead.

The benefits of this *Scripture* extend far beyond mere wealth—
if one’s life or fate is troubled by malevolent stars,
if one lies in bed with restless sleep,
and yet recites this *Scripture* in accordance with its precepts,
then these malevolent stars shall transform their ill fortune into good,
and retreat, bringing forth auspicious fortune.

The Master **Chisongzi** said: *"The people are orphaned and destitute,
each bearing a star upon their brow."*
Yet the stars that shine upon them bring either fortune or calamity—
fortune brings a thousand blessings,
while calamity portends ill omens and punishments.
Those beneath the Three Luminaries must always avoid such ill influences.
Malevolent stars are the stars of calamity—
such as **Luohe** (羅睺), **Jidu** (計都), **Tianpo** (天破), **Tianku** (天哭), **Tianbai** (天敗), and **Tianrui** (天退), among others.

**Photo** (照) refers to when stars align with one’s destiny,
fate, or home—whether at birth, during one’s lifespan,
or in the celestial divisions of one’s abode.
**Kun** (困) means one’s desires are not fulfilled,
pressed down and unable to flourish.
**Ku** (苦) refers to poverty, illness, or danger
that directly afflicts the body.
**Kun and ku in bed and pillow** simply mean
one is trapped in misfortune,
unable to rest or sleep in peace,
lying in bed with no comfort.

Another saying: *"Bed and pillow are disturbed by fear."*
These malevolent stars encompass many—
all celestial omens of calamity that align with one’s destiny,
fate, or home, and all stars of ill fortune.

**Returning and descending auspicious fortune** means
that when malevolent stars shine upon one,
misfortune prevails and no blessings follow.
Yet if one recites this *Scripture* in accordance with its precepts,
the sacred verses shall take effect,
the ill omens shall become auspicious,
and all malevolent stars that afflict one
shall not only fail to bring misfortune,
but shall instead withdraw in silence,
bestowing blessings and fortune,
and descending auspicious fortune.

The influence of stars upon destiny and fate
is inherently fixed.
How then can reciting the *Scripture* cause malevolent stars to bring auspicious fortune?

Heaven and humanity share the same principle—
above and below are interconnected,
and the mechanism of response is swift as light and shadow.
King **Shuanggong of Song** had three sayings of a ruler,
one of which was: *"Retreat when the star **Yinghuo** (荧惑) appears."*

It is not only rulers who can move Heaven—
a filial wife, bearing grief, could bring three years of drought;
a lowly servant, pleading sincerely, could summon frost in the sixth month.
Even common folk, man or woman,
can sway Heaven and Earth,
and stir the spirits and deities—
only fearing their sincerity may not be complete.

If one’s sincerity reaches Heaven,
even a single word can win the trust of the divine.
One need not speak to influence the transformations of fate—
how much more so when the *Scripture* is the essence of Heaven and Earth,
the source from which the Three Luminaries draw their light?

If one recites this *Scripture* in accordance with its precepts,
honoring the sacred verses of the Most Holy,
and fully embracing the profound mysteries of the enlightened,
then malevolent stars shall disperse,
auspicious fortune shall arise,
and ill fate shall turn to blessing.

Humans are all the same—
those who follow the path of virtue shall meet fortune,
those who oppose it shall meet calamity.
*The *Central Admonition Scripture* (中诫经)* says:
*"When stars shine upon a person,
fortune or calamity is self-summoned—
doing great good, the star’s light shall be manifest;
doing no good nor evil, its light shall be faint;
committing minor faults, its light shall scatter;
committing great faults, its light shall vanish.
If malevolent stars afflict one,
it is because of one’s faults—
then ill fate shall respond.
If one is faultless,
the omens shall be averted.
Goodness shall drive away calamity,
and blessings shall descend."*

The *Scripture* says: *"A single thought of evil
summons malevolent stars and vengeful spirits;
a single thought of good
summons auspicious stars and joyous clouds."*
The signs of blessing or ruin
depend upon the purity of one’s thoughts.

Even in times of great peril and disaster,
if one truly upholds this *Scripture*,
the calamities shall retreat—
and yet, are there not some afflictions,
like restless sleep and sudden misfortunes,
that may not be entirely dispelled?

King **Tai Jia** said: *"Heaven creates calamities,
yet they can still be defied."*
This is the same meaning.

If one can propagate the Dao,
praise the nurturing of all things,
and silently turn the true *Scripture*,
entering its divine mysteries to reach cosmic transformation,
then one shall align with Heaven and Earth in virtue,
with the sun and moon in radiance,
with the four seasons in order,
and with the spirits and deities in fortune and calamity.
One shall guide the transformations of fate,
forever transcend the mundane,
and even the spirits and deities shall not dare to obstruct—
life and death shall have no dominion,
and stars shall not be able to confine or limit one.

Let those who observe this *Scripture* strive earnestly.

**Chapter 28 of *The Merits and Virtues* (continued):**
If one’s fate is marked by transgressions,
and they should fall into the hells,
their names recorded in the evil ledgers,
then let their parents, teachers, and elders,
their spouses and children,
recite this *Scripture* for them,
or establish a Daoist hall for their repose,
offering banners, flowers, and provisions.
Thus shall the departed’s evil record be erased,
their spirit reborn in a pure land,
and all suffering beings be liberated together,
receiving this triumphant blessing—
all shall ascend to Heaven above.»

The merits and virtues of this *Scripture* do not merely avert sins in life—
if one’s fate is marked by transgressions and they die prematurely,
their soul and spirit shall descend into the hells,
their names recorded in the ledgers of evil deeds.
Then let their parents, teachers, and elders,
their spouses and children,
recite this *Scripture* for the departed,
or establish a *Dao* hall for their liberation,
offering banners, flowers, and provisions.
Thus shall the departed’s evil records be erased,
their spirit reborn in a pure land,
and all who suffer in the same hells, the same deaths,
the same ledgers of sin—
all shall rely on the *Scripture*’s virtue,
receiving deliverance and salvation,
and attain this supreme and wondrous *Law*’s blessings,
ascending to Heaven above.

*"Command over"* (*命过*)—this means dying before one’s allotted lifespan.
*"Descend into the hells"* (*应入地狱*)—whether from sins committed in past lives or this one,
one must enter the hells and suffer retribution.
The hells include *Yingdu* (酆都), *Iron Enclosure* (铁围), the *Nine Hells*, the *Eighteen Hells*,
the *Twenty-Four Hells*, the *Thirty-Six Hells*, the *Seventy-Two Hells*,
and the *Hell of No Return* (无间), among others.

*"Recorded in the ledgers of evil"* (*注名恶籍*)—their names are inscribed
in the black registers of misdeeds for retribution.
*"Parents, teachers, and elders"* (*父母师长*)—these are the departed’s parents,
their masters, or their senior kin.
*"Spouses and children"* (*夫妻男女*)—whether the departed was a woman or a man,
they must have had a husband or wife;
if not, then their sons, daughters, or other male and female relatives remain.
*"Recite this Scripture for the departed"* (*当为亡人持念是经*)—this is for the living kin

*"Establish a Dao hall"* (*或安置道场*)—to arrange and consecrate a *Dao* hall,

restoring the Heavenly True,
partaking in the Great Dao,
and transcending birth and death.
*The Dao De Jing* says: *"Cease learning, and you will have no worries."*
Yet here it says *"learning the Dao"*—why?
There, *"cease learning"* refers to abandoning the names, forms, and thoughts of learning.
Here, *"learning the Dao"* means learning the boundless, effortless Way.
The Buddhist school holds enlightenment as supreme.
Yet here, enlightenment is but the beginning—
only then does one enter the mountains to cultivate the True Way and learn the Dao.
Thus, the ranks of these two paths are clear.

At times, those who learn the Dao ascend heights, overlook waters,
travel through wondrous landscapes,
and from mountain peaks survey all four directions.
Wherever their gaze extends—
whether mountains, forests, streams, or valleys—
*valleys*, the hollows and deep chasms of mountains—
all living beings, both manifest and latent,
those already born and those yet unborn,
including those born unseen—
whether womb-born, egg-born,
or generated from moisture and filth,
or spontaneously arising from nothingness,
all creeping, flying, swimming, or dormant—
the myriad classes of created life,
their past and present sins and karmic bonds,
all are eradicated.
Their bodies and minds are purified,
free from all entanglements,
and at death, they are reborn in Heaven.

The merits of a True Cultivator’s gaze extending to all things are thus—
how much more so for those who uphold this *Sutra*?
Know that such a one’s virtue/power is boundless,
the very essence of the Dao’s profound藏,
incalculable,
a body of supreme virtue/power.

The cultivator’s heart is vast in compassion and love,
never without benevolence.
Though unseen by sight or hearing,
their gaze encompasses all things,
and in silent reverence, they extend their spirit to rescue all sentient beings,
delivering them from the world.
Thus, they save all beings.

As the Confucian classics say:
*"Achieving harmony, all things are nurtured."*
*"Establishing the Spirit Platform, they observe the encroaching mists,
discerning calamities and omens,
and through subtle means, complete and assist all things."*
What Heaven and Earth cannot reach,
they enable humanity and spirits to receive their natural fate,
returning to the source of transformation—
what sins or karmic bonds could remain?

Those who praise Confucius say:
*"In a single lifetime, one cannot exhaust his learning;
across generations, one cannot fully grasp his depth."*
The ineffable is called divine.
Now, praising those who cultivate the True Way and learn the Dao,
we say: *"the embodiment of the Dao藏’s virtue/power."*
This speaks to its boundless embrace,
its unfathomable depth—
praise that cannot be exhausted.
Those who study the *Sutra* will understand this meaning.

**Continuation of the Merits Chapter (Thirty-Five)**
At that time, the Celestial Sovereign addressed the Jade Emptiness Emperor:
*"Now I have spoken briefly, yet the mysteries remain unfathomed.
If I were to expound fully,
those with errant views, doubts, and disbelief
would never exhaust the *Sutra*’s merits across kalpas."*

At that time—
*(as previously explained)*
The Celestial Sovereign refers to the Primordial Sovereign of the Beginning.
*"To speak"* means to address the Jade Emptiness Emperor of the Supreme Brightness.
*(Alternatively, the Jade Purity Emperor of the Void.)*
*"Now I"* refers to the Primordial Sovereign speaking at this moment.
*"Briefly"* means to outline the essentials.
*"Unfathomed"* means the Dao’s supreme mysteries and highest merits remain unexhausted.

If one were to expound fully upon this *Sutra*,
its merits—merits of reciting and upholding the *Sutra*,
benefiting sentient beings and all things,
benefiting existence and non-existence,
benefiting the formed and the formless,
benefiting self and others,
benefiting heaven and earth—
are already vast indeed.

Yet even so, if one were to expound fully,
those with errant views and disbelief
would still remain unconvinced.

What is spoken of here encompasses:
all beings in one world, past and present,
the existence and destruction of heaven and earth,
as well as the three thousand great thousand worlds,
from kalpa to kalpa, countless kalpas,
one future age, all future ages,
from the beginning without beginning,
to the end without end,
whether knowing or unaware,
whether perceiving or not perceiving,
whether conceptualizable or inconceivable,
whether finite or infinite—
all merits, both within this *Sutra* and for those who uphold it,
if widely proclaimed and expounded in their profundity,
would still leave the common folk—
the vulgar and the ordinary—
with errant views, doubts, and disbelief.

*"Vulgar"* refers to the common people of the world;
*"flow"* refers to those of ordinary inclinations.

Like water flowing, it cannot extract the finest grains.
*"Evil views"* are partial and crooked, not upright and vast.
*"Doubt"* arises when wisdom does not prevail—ambiguous, undecided.
*"Delusion"* stirs from private thoughts, tangled and confused, unable to discern right from wrong, a chaotic jumble of misguided perception—thus they disbelieve this *Sutra* holds boundless benefits.

The *Sutra*’s virtues exhaust even kalpas in speech,
countless kalpas beyond reckoning—still, they cannot be fully spoken.
Some say: "Exhausting the kalpas in recounting leaves speech still incomplete."
Fundamentally, the Primordial Origin endures eternally,
kalpas are endless, the *Sutra*’s virtues unfathomable,
the Great Dao immeasurable—
yet speech can never exhaust it.

The Great Dao is beyond words,
the Marvelous Law beyond form,
the True Scripture beyond letters—
what can be applied and received,
seen and heard,
spoken and attained,
are all but second meanings.

Thus, the Most High Sage manifested across countless kalpas,
preached to twelve thousand heavens,
traveled distant realms,
composed countless *Sutras*,
one manifestation lasting seventeen hundred years,
expounding the *Sutra* over ninety thousand times—
yet still declared, *"I do not know its name,"*
and by force named it *Dao*.

Confucius, inheriting the past and opening the future,
enlightening the ages to come, said, *"I know nothing."*
The Śākyamuni Buddha spoke for forty-nine years,
expounding the *Sutra* in over three hundred assemblies,
composing the Three Baskets of *Sūtras*, *Vinaya*, and *Abhidharma*—
yet still said, *"I now speak briefly, unable to exhaust it."*

Yán Zǐ stood alone, his heart in quietude, said, *"Though I wish to follow, I cannot find the way."*

This *Sutra* is the root of all teachings—
its virtues, if spoken, cannot be exhausted,
the highest of virtues.
Spoken of, it cannot be fully grasped.
Spoken, people still cannot truly understand.

Thus, the Confucian *wuwei* governance,
the Daoist true and profound virtues,
the Buddhist offering of life and body—
the righteousness of the Western import—
are all beyond what can be transmitted in words.

Ah! The wonder of the Wheel-turning Sage—
heart and hand in perfect accord.

Zhuangzi, the master of the Three Teachings,
thus beyond the six directions—
preserved without discussion,
sank without debate—
not that he could not speak,
but words easily stir confusion—
better to remain silent.

Even the Master rarely spoke of fate,
for the Nature and Dao are beyond hearing.

The Buddha spoke of countless worldly scenes,
dividing them into matters and principles—
setting aside their boundless, unverifiable vastness,
even if grounded, what cannot be spoken remains much.
Those who follow his teachings assume the Buddha spoke what no one else could—
foolishly deeming it lofty—
yet he was born in a distant land,
among strange peoples and customs,
a rugged, remote place,
surrounded by many,
and the Buddha accommodated their views.
China did not know.

Foolishly claiming the Buddha’s vision was vast—
observe China alone: within a hundred *li*, customs differ.
Yan, Yue, Tai, and Qi—
mountains and rivers shift the winds—
those who do not traverse them cannot know.
How much more so the distant Western Regions?
Even with historical records, they are but hearsay and miscellany—
how can they be trusted without error?

Men love the strange and unusual,
without investigating truth—
if the Buddha truly knew all,
why did his scriptures not enter China in Tang texts,
translated three times before becoming coherent?
Since they did not know Tang speech,
what he spoke must have been of neighboring lands—
or perhaps, like Zhuangzi’s parables, some were allegorical.

People do not examine closely,
erroneously judging superiority—
how their love of the strange exceeds!

Alas, not speaking of all realms
prevents further confusion—
briefly speaking of virtues and transformations
to awaken the ignorant,
revealing true intent,
manifesting the correct Law—
this is why the Dao brings real benefit.

Scholars should diligently investigate further.

*(End of the "Virtues" Chapter, continuing the thirty-sixth section.)*

Where the Dao resides, both gods and mortals hold it in reverence, hence the Emperor commands the ten-directional holy hosts to shield and protect.

Yet this is only for those who are loyal, filial, respectful, and abstain from lust, killing, theft, and falsehood.
Upholding the scripture must be rooted in virtuous conduct, merging the heart with the Dao—then the Dao itself will return to them.

Some say, *"The Dao withdraws from the world, avoiding rulers and kin, thus not practicing filial piety or loyalty."*
They do not know the Dao’s profound precepts are most strict—guarding, preserving, and refining, never daring to violate precepts or bring shame to their bodies or kin.
With utmost sincerity and firmness, they first repay the Four Graces—how could they ever forget their rulers and kin, or be unfilial or disloyal?
Thus, the True Lord composed *The Scripture of Pure Clarity on Filial Piety and Loyalty*, to reveal the Dao’s true filial piety and loyalty.

「Cultivate the mind and refine the body—this is not achieved through mere chanting and reading, but through sincere, silent practice, with utmost sincerity and selflessness. The Emperor’s virtue is boundless, and the benefits of this Scripture are supreme—how greatly do people respect and receive it?

The *Chapter of Protection* decrees: The Vajra Warriors who command life and death, the Four Heavenly Kings of the gates, the Five Sacred Mountains and Four Great Waters, as well as all named mountains, the Four Seas and Nine Rivers, the Twelve River Sources, forests, valleys, streams, and marshes—all their ruling deities and their retinues—shall cover and protect those who receive and uphold this Scripture. The Emperor’s decree extends to all local deities of the lands, including those of ditches and canals, as well as all great-power ghostly kings, commanding them to cover and protect those who receive and uphold this Scripture.

The Twelve River Sources are now recorded as thirteen names, for two waters share the same source—thus it is called the Twelve River Sources. The decree commands the Subduing Kings and Heavenly Vajra Warriors. The Four Heavenly Kings of the gates are the Eastern, Western, Southern, and Northern gatekeepers. The Five Sacred Mountains are: the Eastern **Tài**, Southern **Héng**, Western **Huá**, Northern **Héng**, and Central **Sōng**. The Four Great Waters refer to the deities of the **Jiāng**, **Hé**, **Huái**, and **Jì** rivers.

All named mountains in the world are included. The Four Seas are the Eastern, Western, Southern, and Northern seas. The Nine Rivers include: **Yángzǐ**, **Qiantáng**, **Hànyáng**, **Huìyáng**, **Hùntóng**, **Jǐn Jiāng**, **Xiāng Jiāng**, **Wūlóng**, and **Yālù**, encompassing all rivers.

The Twelve River Sources are the origins of the Yellow River, the world’s vital vein: such as **Kūnlún**, **Yǔmén**, **Xīngxiù Hǎi**, **Huǒdūn Nǎo’ér**, and its tailing streams, **Fāxiè** and **Fáxiè**, along with the roots of other rivers that flow into it. Another account states that when discussing the Yellow River’s sources, **Kūnlún** has nine wells and seven springs, not just twelve. The Twelve River Sources pertain to the nine rivers—**Túhài**, **Tàishǐ**, **Mǎxiá**, **Fùfǔ**, **Húsū**, **Jiǎnjié**, **Gōu pán**, **Gēlín**, **Rǔ**, **Hàn**, **Huái**, and **Sì**—as well as the **Rǔ**, **Hàn**, **Huái**, and **Sì** waters, totaling twelve.

The Yellow River is the supreme deity of all rivers. Rivers like **Jīng**, **Wèi**, **Yí**, **Wèn**, **Shēn**, **Wéi**, **Hùtuó**, **Xīngxié**, and **Ruòshuǐ**, along with all other rivers, are its subordinate deities. The forests and mountains encompass all terrestrial groves and peaks. The streams and marshes are all the world’s flowing waters and wetlands. *川* refers to moving waters; *泽* means stagnant waters. All ruling deities of mountains, forests, streams, and marshes, along with their retinues, are commanded to cover and protect those who uphold this Scripture.

In all hazardous and difficult places, let them have no worries and find stability—this refers specifically to those who hold the Scripture. Wherever the Emperor’s decree reaches, all local deities and responsive spirits of the lands shall heed it. *沟* (gōu) are dry channels, either in mountains or earth; *渠* (qú) are waterways. *等神* (děngshén) includes all minor deities beyond ditches and canals.

All great-power ghostly kings are likewise commanded to cover and protect those who uphold this Scripture.

The essence of this Imperial Scripture aligns with the treasures of all Immortals, the teachings of all Buddhas, the practices of all Heavens, the reverence of all deities, and the recitations of all people. Demons and malevolent spirits submit themselves. Indeed, mountains are steadied by it, and waters flow endlessly—its protection is strict and unyielding.

If those who uphold the Scripture are its very guardians, how then could they dare to be negligent? A single moment of carelessness brings grave sin and deep consequences.

Truly, Confucius said: *"The petty do not know Heaven’s decree and do not fear it."* They mock the great, scorn the words of the Sage—this is the petty. Even in observing this Scripture, one must still guard against arrogance and exert diligence.

The *Fifth Chapter of Protection* concludes.»

The **Scripture** commands all **demons (魔)** and **external heretics (外道)**—whether **Heavenly Demons (天魔)**, **Earthly Demons (地魔)**, **Demon Kings (魔王)**, **Demon Folk (魔民)**, or **Demon Women (魔女)**—to tremble and submit, vanish their forms and flee their traces, soar high beyond the seas, and retreat far to distant realms.

Thus, all **mountain spirits, forest deities, ancestral shrines, and temple guardians (山林社稷祠庙之属)**, as well as **every ghost and spirit (一切鬼神)**, shall **self-destruct and vanish (自消灭)**.

The **Five Directions’ Plague and Epidemic Demons (五方行病瘟疫鬼帅)**, **all malevolent ghosts and spirits (诸恶鬼神)**, including the **Wind King (风王)** and **water monsters (水怪)**, the **sinful retributive dragons (孽音业龙)** and **malevolent deities (妖神)**, **earthly spirits (土精)** and **water sirens (水魅)**, shall all **self-destruct and vanish (尽自消灭)**.

The **Five Empties (五虚)** and **Six Depletions (六耗)**, **unusual dreams (梦寐乖常)**, **sorcery along wild paths (野道咒咀)**, and **poisonous hexes (蛊毒之类)** shall likewise **self-destruct and vanish (皆自消灭)**.

For those who **uphold the Scripture with a devout heart (持经人心欲愿者)**, all **whims shall be fulfilled (一切如意)**, and **every desire shall be satisfied (皆得满足)**.

**Astonishing and resounding (慑音聂)!**

The **Scripture commands (令)**—by **imperial decree (勅命)**, **prohibition (禁令)**, and **extermination (剿除)**—all **demons (诸魔)** and **external heretics (外道)**:

**External heretics (外道)** are those who indulge in **lewd speech (淫辞)**, **perverse doctrines (邪说)**, **deviant practices (僻行)**, **miscellaneous techniques (杂法)**, **side-door sorcery (旁门)**, and **petty occult arts (小术)**, including **private methods (私技)** numbering **three thousand six hundred, ninety-six kinds, or thirty-six thousand (三千六百、九十六种、三万六千等)**.

The **Scripture commands (令)**—by **imperial decree (勅命)**, **prohibition (禁令)**, and **extermination (剿除)**—that they **all tremble and submit (悉皆慑伏)**.

All **demons (诸魔)**—**trepidation (慑)** is the **submission of the heart in awe (惊畏心服)**, **subjugation (伏)** is the **retraction and surrender (收敛归伏)**. They **conceal their forms and flee their traces (潜形遁迹)**—**concealment (潜)** means to **hide their likeness (藏其形象)**, daring not to reveal themselves; **flight (遁)** means to **evade their traces (逃其影迹)**, daring not to linger.

Though the forms of these **demons (诸魔)** may outwardly appear **bewitching (妖艳)** and their illusory shapes **strange and beautiful (幻象奇美)**, their true nature is **obstructed (阻)**, unseen by mortals. This **Scripture’s true teachings (真法)** shatter the **ghosts’ resolve (破鬼之胆)** and **shatter the demons’ hearts (碎魔之心)**. No demon can escape its scrutiny—**awe-struck by the profound and potent decrees (玄律丹劲)**, they dare not linger, lest their **ugly essence (丑质)** be exposed.

The **external heretics (外道)** seek to **obscure the truth (乱真)** with their words. When the **True Dao (正道)** prevails, **deviant doctrines (邪说)** fade; when the **Great Dao (大道)** is honored, **side-paths (傍门)** are abandoned. Once the **imperial decree (帝命)** is proclaimed, they dare not persist.

To **soar beyond the seas (高飞海外)**—their **demonic deeds (魔行)** leave no trace—**a metaphor for utter disappearance (飞言)**. How could **external heretics (外道)** be said to **fly (飞)**? To **restrain the heart and ease the mind (格心易虑)**, to **turn toward transformation and abandon selfishness (向化忘私)**, to **ascend beyond the seas (高腾海外)**—this is the **common phrase (俗语言)** for **the soul fleeing to the heavens (魂飞天外)** and **the spirit dispersing into the nine heavens (魄散九霄)**. They flee to distant lands, **daring not to remain in their former places (不敢居其故地)**.

Thus, all **mountain spirits, forest deities, land gods (社), grain gods (稷), temple spirits (祠), and ancestral shrines (庙)**—those that demand **blood sacrifices and offerings (血食)**—**every ghost and spirit (鬼神)** shall **self-destruct (自消灭)**.

**Mountains and forests (山林)**—as previously explained. **Land gods (社)** are **earth spirits (土神)**; **grain gods (稷)** are **harvest deities (谷神)**. **Temples (祠)** are **overseers (司)** and **sacrificial rites (祀)**—where deities **oversee and are invoked (神之司临)**. **Shrines (庙)** are **places of worship (朝)**, where **ancestral spirits are honored (妾神於庙)** and **sacrifices of blood, grain, and wine (血食享牲醴)** are offered.

All these **spirits (鬼神)** are **worthy of veneration (宜祀者)**—how then can they **self-destruct (自消灭)**? If **spirits are summoned without proper rites (神邀祭祀)**, they will **act unjustly (为不直)**; if **the people flatter ghosts and spirits (民谄鬼神)**, they will **act corruptly (为不正)**.

Thus, the **Master Sa Zhengren** subdued the **King of Spirits (王灵官)** and reformed the **City City God (禁城隍)**; **Ximen Bao**, governor of **Jizhou**, cast the **shaman into the water** to restrain the **River Spirit (河神)**. How much more so when **evil spirits feign divinity to deceive people**, and **people revere falsehoods to mislead the common folk**?

Therefore, **Hu Ying** in his governance of **Guangdong** destroyed **illusionary Buddhas** and slew **demonic serpents**, punishing monks to free the ignorant masses. Now it is said that **all ghosts and spirits shall self-destruct (消灭)**—following the **Scripture’s decree**, they **no longer bestow blessings or calamities**, and their **threat and influence vanish**.

The **Five Directions’ Plague and Epidemic Spirit Generals (五方行病瘟疫鬼帅)**—these **malevolent ghosts and spirits (诸恶鬼神)** are not the **Plague Spirit Generals (行病鬼帅)**, but rather **the world’s malevolent and powerful ghosts (世之厉鬼强神)**. Alongside them, the **Wind Sovereigns (并行风之王)**, **water monsters (水中之怪)**, **violent and sinful dragons (作孽暴龙)**, **portentous and malevolent spirits (妖异邪神)**, **earthly sprites and wood demons (土精木魅)**—all shall **self-destruct**.

The **Five Emptinesses and Six Depletions (五虚六耗)**—the **emptiness of spirit, qi, blood, and body (精神气血身五虚)**, the **withering of the six pulses (六脉衰耗)**—lead to **dreams contrary to nature (梦寐乖常)** and **restless soul and spirit (魂魄不宁)**.

It is also said that the **Five Emptinesses and Six Depletions (五虚六耗)** are like **heaven’s weeping and ruin (天哭破败)**, the **stars of calamity (丧门、太岁、大耗、小耗、飞康、空亡、黄旛、豹尾、九果、赤口、白舌)**—**malevolent omens, killing stars, and malevolent deities (恶厌神杀凶星、作祸神鬼之属)**—all **malevolent affairs (一切辱事)**, **wild Daoist rites (野道)**, **evil spells (邪法)**, **curses and incantations (咒诅妖语)**, whether **curses or oaths (或咒或誓)**, and **poisonous hexes and bewitchments (及蛊毒魇昧之类)**—all shall **self-destruct**.

For those who **hold this Scripture with sincere desire (持经人心欲愿者)**, all **schemes and aspirations (谋望)** that align with their hearts’ wishes (趁心如意) shall be **fulfilled without obstruction (皆得满足，无有违逆)**.

The **virtuous and moral (道德之士)**—ghosts and spirits **revere and hold them in awe (鬼神钦重)**—and all **malevolence and evil shall vanish (凶邪尽消)**.

When **Xiang Sang died**, **Zi Tong drove away the plague (梓橦驱瘟)**, **Jing Yang subdued the river dragon (旌阳伏蛟)**, **Master Zu’s ancestor subdued demons (祖天师伏魔)**, and **Master Sa restrained ghosts (萨祖禁鬼)**—all had **clear and manifest effects (皆有明效)**.

Ah! **Wang Yanzhang** was a **hero of integrity (烈士)**—though he **stole the wish for execution (盗愿刑戮)**, he **did not allow Yanzhang to know of external Dao (外道)**, truly a **man of virtue (诚有德之铃然者)**.

Yet, **human beings’ Three Corpses (三尸)**, **Five Burdens (五累)**, **Seven Emotions (七情)**, **Six Desires (六欲)**, and **Nine Consciousnesses (九识)**—**lower evil (下恶)** harms them, and **they deceive themselves (欺不能正己)**. If one **subdues evil and eliminates calamity (伏邪除凶)**, and **advances on the Dao (正进道)**, **severing the Three Corpses (斩三尸)**, **eliminating the Five Burdens (除五累)**, **extinguishing emotions and desires (情欲尽)**, and **removing malevolent consciousness (识恶除)**, then **one’s own wishes shall be fulfilled (己愿尽)**, and **external evils shall vanish while auspiciousness arrives (外邪消，凶散吉临)**.

**Protection and Upholding of the Six Chapters**
Even if one **cannot follow the prescribed rituals (未能遵依科教)**, **observe fasts (修崇斋醮)**, but only **maintains purity and upholds precepts (清净持戒)**, **devotedly accepts (专一信受)**, **honors and reveres (尊重敬慕)** this Scripture, and **participates in fasting rites (并同修斋)**, those who **uphold pure precepts (护持净戒)** shall have **unobstructed merit (功德坦然无碍)**, **freedom and ease (自在消遥)**, and are called **"Saints Among Men (人中圣)"**, with **enduring virtue and wisdom (德慧长新)**, equal to the **True Persons (诸真人)**.

Those who **receive and uphold the Scripture according to its law (如法受持经者)** shall have **merit beyond measure (功德莫量)**.

Even if one **cannot follow the esoteric rituals and precepts (未能遵依玄科教典)**, **observe grand fasts (修崇大斋醮)**, but only **remains pure and unstained (清净无染)**, **upholds precepts with singular devotion (持戒专一)**, and **adheres to the Daoist precept codes (持守道门戒律)**—whether the **Five Precepts, Eight Precepts, Twelve Provisional Precepts, Eighteen Precepts, Twenty-Four Precepts, Thirty-Six Precepts, Seventy-Two Precepts, One Hundred Twenty Precepts, One Hundred Eighty Precepts, Three Hundred Great Precepts, or the Six Hundred Pure Precepts of the Celestial Maidens (女冠六百净戒)**—if one **concentrates with wholehearted sincerity (专心致志)**, **devotes oneself to this precept chapter with unwavering resolve (持此戒品专一，坚固无二)**, **accepts and reveres it in faith (信受尊重)**, **accepts and practices it sincerely (信受奉行)**, **holds it in solemn awe (钦严尊重)**, and **reveres and admires this Scripture (诚敬仰慕是此经典)**, then even if one **only maintains purity, upholds precepts, and accepts them with singular devotion (或作但能清净持戒，专一信受，尊重敬慕读者)**, all are included.

They shall **participate in fasting rites together (并同修斋)**, and those who **uphold pure precepts (护持净戒者)** shall have **equal merit (功德一般)**. All **deities shall respect and protect them (诸神敬佑)**.

It is also said that **if one maintains purity and singular devotion (自己清净专一)**, **upholding the pure precepts they have taken (护持所守净戒)**, their **merit shall be unobstructed (是人功德，坦然无碍)**.

*"Tan"* means **level (平)**, *"kuang"* means **broad (广)**. If the **heart is divided (心有二)**, then **merit is not genuine (功德不实)**. If **precepts are not upheld (戒不持)**, they **taint merit (於功德有玷)**. When **mind and body are pure (心身清净)**, **precepts are upheld with singular devotion (持戒专)**, **acceptance is sincere (信受切)**, and **the Scripture is honored with reverence (尊敬经典)**, with **no attachment in the heart (心无染)**, **no division in the heart (心无二)**, and **no deficiency or obstruction (无有亏欠萦击)**, then **merit is truly genuine (功德真实)**, and **how can there be any obstruction (自是坦然，又有何碍)?** One shall **dwell in freedom and ease (自在逍遥)**.

---

From birth, human nature is **unbound and unrestrained (无拘无困)**. Yet when **encumbered by external influences (客感物累)**, one is **busy and labored (忙忙苦苦)**, losing **one’s innate harmony (无复自如)**, and **how can true joy (快乐) be found?**

When **the heart is pure and faith is true (清净正信)**, **external burdens are cast aside (无复物累)**, and **great freedom (大自在)** is attained, **joy becomes everlasting (常乐逍遥)**. Such a person is called **the Sage among mortals (人中圣)**, not merely one who **wanders freely (逍遥之人)**.

**Pure and true (消净正信)**, **transcending common humanity (高出人俦)**, this is the **Sage among mortals (人中圣人)**. **Virtue and wisdom are ever renewed (德慧常新)**, **practice aligns with insight (习与智长)**, and **transformation harmonizes with the heart (化与心成)**. When **perception and understanding are true (闻见真)**, **intellect merges with intuition (智虑融)**, and **external burdens are forgotten (物累忘)**, **true nature shines undimmed (性真湛)**.

**Virtue is daily renewed (德日新)**, **wisdom ever brightened (慧日明)**—this is the **ever-renewing virtue and wisdom (德慧常新)**. Those who **share in the true way (同诸真人)** are those who **hold scripture and attain the Dao (清净正信者同持经得道)****,** the **true beings of the heavens (诸天真人)**.

The **pure and true (清净)**—**upholding precepts (持戒)**, **singular in devotion (专一)**, **sincere in acceptance (信受切)**, **reverent in honoring scripture (尊重敬慕)**—**do so without calculation of merit (非有计功之心)**, nor **for human intent (为人之意)**. Their **actions are without ulterior motive (无所为而为)**, **utterly free from deceit or interruption (绝无虚假间断)**.

This is as the **Master Kong (孔子)** spoke: **"In haste or at leisure, no deviation (造次终食，颠沛无违)."**
This is as the *Zhōng Yōng* (《中庸》) states: **"None enter without finding their own fulfillment (无入而不自得)."**
Zhuangzi expounded the **essence of *Xiāoyáo* (逍遥)**, and **Bai Jianchuan (海蟾)** sang the **ode of *Kuàihuó* (快活)**.
The **Buddhist teaching of Great Freedom (大自在)**, the **Confucian principle of Daily Renewal (日新)**, and **"Revering the old and knowing the new (温故而知新)"**—all are **natural manifestations (自然之效)**.
**How could there be any contrivance or imitation (假借)?** **How could there be any forced adoption (勉强袭取)?**

Ah! **Pure and true (清净正信)**, even **without ritual instruction (不依科教)**, nor **observing fasts and offerings (修斋醮)**, **such natural merit (自然功德)** still exists. **Thus, the Dao’s profound essence (道旨玄科)** is **found only in the true substance of scripture (实体经义)**.
**Ritual instruction, fasts, and offerings (科教斋醮)**—the **Universal Law (普法)**—**are but means to propagate the Dao’s transformation (以演道化)**.
Chen Xiyi (陈希夷) **mocked the *Dù Rén Jīng* (度人经)**, yet **his attainment of the Dao (成道)** was **true adherence to scripture’s essence (盖真持经旨)**.

**Today’s fasts and offerings (斋醮)** lack **clear efficacy (无明效)** because **there are elaborate rites (有盛仪)**, yet **no true cultivation (无真修)**.
If **one is pure and true (清净正信)** and **further observes fasts and offerings (更修斋醮)**, then **merit is greatly enhanced (功益大)**.
Without **fasts and offerings (无斋醮)**, yet **with true sincerity (有真诚)**, merit **is still divine (功亦神)**.
If **sincerity is absent (无真诚)**, then **fasts and offerings (斋醮)** are **mere formalities (文具)**—**how much greater the fault (宁无过乎)!**

**Chapter on Protection (护持品七章)**
At that time, the **Celestial Sovereign, Emperor of Heaven (昊天上帝)**, upon hearing these words, **bowed in reverence (稽首)** before the **Celestial Sovereign (帝)** and sang:

**Great is the Supreme Dao (大哉至道)!**
**Formless and nameless (无形无名).**
**Vast through countless eons (渺渺亿劫),**
**The Yellow Way (黄道) opens in purity (开清).**

**Divine purity shines radiant (神清朗耀),**
**The Nine *Qi* (九炁) exhale their essence (吐精).**
**The Jade Void (玉虚) glows clear (澄辉),**
**The Great Mists (太霞) ascend in brilliance (高明).**

**The Jade Sovereign (玉皇) initiates transformation (开化),**
**Universally nurturing (溥度) all heavenly and human beings (天人).**
**The Three Primordial Forces (三元) nourish the Dao (道养),**
**The Two Symbols (二象) encompass all life (摄生).**

**Decayed trees and ancient roots (朽树故根),**
**Though withered, are made to flourish anew (已枯使荣).**
**Creeping and crawling beings (蠢动蜎息),**
**Attain eternal life (长生) and transcend their forms (化形).**

**Those who bear in womb or conceive (怀胎含孕),**
**All achieve birth and growth (俱得生成).**
**The departed whose life has passed (亡者命过),**
**Their spirits return to the Three Pure Ones (魂归三清),**
**Their *pò* (魄) undergo refinement and liberation (受炼度),**
**Ascending to the Southern Palace (南宫飞升).**

**Today is a great auspice (今日大吉)!**
**All are granted radiance (皆得光明).**
**The Five Emperors (五帝) reflect and mirror (鉴映),**
**Proclaiming to all sentient beings (普告万灵).**

**Heavenly deities and earthly spirits (天神地祇),**
**And all river sources (及诸河源),**
**The Five Sacred Peaks and Four Great Waterways (五岳四渎),**
**And all named mountains (及诸名山),**
**The Mystic Void (洞玄), the Mystic Emptiness (洞虚),**
**The Mystic Abyss (洞空), the Mystic Immortals (洞仙),**
**The Boundless Greatest Sage (无极大圣),**
**The Supreme True Venerable Deity (至真尊神),**
**The Endless and Boundless (无穷无极),**
**All oversee and liberate beings (溥监度生).**

**Evil roots are severed (恶根断绝),**
**The Mystic Register records their names (玄都记名).**
**All true beings gather in ranks (众真班列),**
**Attending to the Celestial Sovereign’s decree (成听帝言).**

**The Scripture is the Sovereign’s commandment (经是帝勑),**
**Preserved and chanted by those who uphold humanity (保诵持人).**
**To the utmost degree of the Dao’s shore (至度道岸),**
**No calamity shall intrude (无使灾侵).**

**I bear the Sovereign’s mandate (我奉帝命),**
**All shall heed (一切咸听).**

At that time, the **Vision of Understanding (解见)** appeared as before. The **Celestial Sovereign, Emperor of Heaven (昊天上帝)**, upon hearing these words, **pointed to the merit of protection (指上护持功德言)** and **bowed in reverence (稽首)** before the **Jade Sovereign (玉帝)** while singing in praise:

**Great is the Supreme Dao (大哉至道)!**
**Its magnitude is beyond measure (大莫可量),**
**Its reach is beyond attainment (至不可及).**

**Formless and nameless (无形无名),**
**Unseen and unheard (不见不闻),**
**Its name is but a forced designation (名亦强称).**

**Vast through countless eons (渺渺亿劫),**
**Without beginning or end (无始无终),**
**Spanning innumerable ages (历劫无数),**
**A hundred million is called *yì* (亿), yet truly it is beyond number (要之举大数言，实无数耳).**

**The Yellow Way (黄道) opens in purity (开清),**
**Marking auspicious times and joyous gatherings (吉时庆会),**
**The Heavenly Dao (天道) is made clear and open (开通).**

**Divine purity shines radiant (神清朗耀),**
**The divine wind is ever pure (神风永清),**
**Its brilliance is undimmed (朗耀光明).**

**The Nine *Qi* exhale their essence (九炁吐精):**
**The Nine *Qi* are *yān* (炎), *yǎn* (演), *hào* (昊), *jǐng* (景), *dào* (道), *hún* (混), *dòng* (洞), *hào* (浩) and others (等).**
**Exhaling essence (吐精)**—the **Yellow Way opens to dispel death and celebrate rebirth (黄道开死庆消)**,**
**The Nine *Qi* display their radiance (九炁呈辉),**
**Exhaling essence in dazzling splendor (吐精炫瑞).**

**The Jade Void (玉虚) glows clear (澄辉),**
**The Jade Light (玉光) is pure and luminous (虚明),**
**Its clarity is undimmed (澄然清辉).**
**Some say the Jade Void (玉虚) manifests the Heavenly Radiance (天呈辉).**

**The Great Mists (太霞) ascend in brilliance (高明),**

The ancient sages and worthies had birth and death, faced disasters and misfortune—how could they claim to preserve life and avert disasters? Rather, they preserved the Heavenly Mandate and maintained true *qi*, enduring trials with daily ease, meeting death with serenity, finding no distinction between joy and sorrow. This is the true meaning of preserving life and averting disasters through the scripture.

It sweeps away all inauspiciousness—where the scripture’s power resides, all calamities vanish in secret. The virtuous receive Heaven’s favor, and all disasters are forever removed, leaving no trace of ill fortune.

As for kings and nobles: the sovereign of all under Heaven is called the *Son of Heaven* (天子), the *Emperor* (皇), or the *Sage Emperor* (帝). In the Zhou, they were called *Kings* (王). In later times, a feudal lord ruling a single state is called a *King* (王), and a vassal holding a fief is called a *Marquess* (侯). In antiquity, a marquess ruled over a hundred *li*.

Those who uphold this scripture bring their nation’s lineage to great peace. Bandits and rebels are naturally subdued—*subdued* meaning pacified. When a land follows the Dao, internal harmony and external might prevail; wicked rebels and bandits do not rise, and the four borderlands submit in tribute, all under Heaven at ease, with no wars on the frontiers. Those who possess this Dharma and embody its transformative power are held in reverence by the Celestial Worthies. It is a treasure to be guarded in secrecy—though the Great Dao universally saves all, the unworthy should not be given it lightly. The Buddha’s *True Dharma Eye Treasury* is not casually revealed to all. Confucius said: ‘Those of mediocre or lesser capacity cannot be taught the highest truths.’ True understanding must come from the heart. To treat it lightly is to profane the Heavenly.

The scripture says *guard it in secrecy*—let those who observe it understand its meaning on their own.

All beings bear karmic consciousness, each drawn to their own inclinations—whether good or evil, endlessly cycling through rebirth, unable to escape. The Great Saints and Perfect Ones transcend past habits, uproot defilements, purify consciousness and karma, sever all realms of existence, and with all obstructions removed, suffer no retribution or rebirth.

The great bodhisattvas, minor immortals, minor saints, divine generals, and ghostly spirits—those of virtue take cultivation as their path, those of vice are bound by their deeds. Virtuous beings need no further mention; the wicked, however, sink into their karmic prisons, their retributions endless, with no escape or remedy. When their karma is exhausted, they are reborn elsewhere, only to be dragged again by karmic ties, lost in delusion, wandering through kalpas without end. Such is their karmic fate—truly pitiful.

The Four Venerable Ones, moved by great compassion, implored the Celestial Venerable to speak of these retributive sufferings.

Now, regarding the teachings on retribution: Confucian scholars deny it not. *Tai Jia* said: *"When Heaven inflicts calamity, it may still be averted; when a man brings calamity upon himself, there is no escape."* The classics say: *"Reward the virtuous, punish the licentious."* And again: *"The responses of Heaven and man are swift as echoes."* How could they deny retribution?

The Master said: *"The gentleman cherishes the penal codes."* And again: *"Fear the Heavenly Mandate."* Thus, he does not himself do evil. When Dao and righteousness delight the heart, there is no other path.

In past dynasties, at the *xiangyin* and archery rites, they taught the people through lectures on law and order, guiding them not by coercion but by nurturing their inherent goodness.

「The teachings of both Dao and Buddhism on retribution and penal codes serve only to uproot their karmic inclinations and lead them toward great virtue. Alas! Only the sage, through divine instruction and governance, commands the reverence of all.

The Jade Emperor’s merit and virtue are supreme, hence the scriptures clearly demonstrate retribution to rescue beings from evil paths, never deceiving the multitude. If one does not cultivate the True Dao, but merely dazzles others with talk of reward and punishment, this is to deceive them. Those who study the scriptures must renounce desire and attain the True Dao to escape personal retribution and suffering, only then can they save and guide the world.

The *Yingying* [應驗] chapters continue with twelve more sections. At that time, the Heavenly Sage addressed the Four True Ones [四真人], saying: *"If there are beings in the world who are obstinate, fierce, and cruel—unbenevolent creatures whose speech and deeds harm all beings—who day and night face the Daoist images without reverence, uttering blasphemous words, they shall incur the crime of falling into the Five Boundless [五無間] Prisons.*

If they encounter one who holds this scripture, who employs all means to persuade, guide, and rescue them, then such beings—able to extinguish their evil thoughts, take faith in this scripture, and purify all their crimes without remainder—shall be redeemed. At that time, the Original Heavenly Sage addressed the Four True Ones of Compassionate Salvation and Deliverance [慈悲度厄等四真人], saying:

*"If there are beings in the world who are obstinate, fierce, and cruel—those bold and coarse in name, unbenevolent beings whose speech and deeds harm all beings—who day and night face the Daoist images without reverence, uttering blasphemous words, they shall incur the crime of falling into the Five Boundless [五無間] Prisons. The Five Prisons are the great penal realms of the Underworld; non-sages have no recourse, thus they fall into these crimes. Observe the solar laws [陽律] for blasphemous slander, and you shall know the gravity of slandering the divine.

If they encounter one who holds this scripture, who employs all means to save and guide them, then those who defy the divine and slander the scriptures have deep-rooted karmic tendencies, clinging stubbornly to their delusions, lacking faith. The scripture-holder, through boundless compassion and skillful means, awakens, persuades, and leads them, revealing their true nature, fostering benevolent thoughts. Thus, those who defy the divine and slander the scriptures, if they extinguish all their evil thoughts, take faith in this scripture, and devote themselves wholly to it, shall have their crimes purified without remainder. Their karmic debts shall be erased, retribution fulfilled, and they shall forever be free from transgression, never returning to cyclic suffering, always pure and clear, with evil retribution forever removed and no unresolved karmic debts remaining.

The Five Boundless [五無間] hells—where crimes are difficult to purify—if one steadfastly takes faith in the True Scriptures, the evil roots shall be severed, all defilements extinguished, and what bonds remain? The roots and defilements shall be utterly destroyed, with no karmic residue. The divine virtue and scriptural efficacy are the greatest benefits; both Dao and Buddhism emphasize crimes of retribution, sternly warning against defying the divine and slandering the scriptures.

Confucian scholars often admonish irreverence toward spirits and gods—does this mean Confucians do not revere the divine or honor scriptures? The *Book of Odes* states: *"Do not disgrace your birth."* Master Zhang [張子] says: *"To not fear the gods peering through the roof beams is to disgrace your birth."* Again, it says: *"Cultivate the heart and nurture the nature, without negligence."* The teachings of both Dao and Buddhism speak of revering the divine, honoring the scriptures, and fostering the heart to cultivate the Dao, never falling short in devotion to Heaven, Earth, and the divine, and embodying the scriptures’ truth.

Confucians teach that one should not flatter the gods, warning only against seeking rewards through improper reverence. Serving Heaven means fearing Heaven’s mandate, aspiring to Heaven’s will, and honoring the teachings of the ancient kings, with solemn respect like a swift-chariot race or a galloping steed—Confucianism and the two teachings are one in this regard. If sacrifices bring no benefit, reverence is insufficient, and the mandate of Heaven is not to be feared, these are hollow words. Confucian scholars also condemn them sternly—why single out the other two traditions?

Alas! Benevolence and malevolence, reverence and neglect, all arise from the heart. If one can sever emotional desires, abandon worldly perceptions, empty the Five Aggregates [五蘊], and remove the Five Fetters [五累], then one shall not be bound by the Five Elements [五行], nor by Heaven and Earth, and the Five Boundless [五無間] Prisons shall not touch them. The Buddha says: *"To chant the Buddha’s name transforms the fiery pit into a lotus pond."* Mencius says: *"To recite the words of Yao and follow Yao’s deeds is to be Yao himself."* Thus, the true efficacy of virtue and goodness is immediately manifest.

**Chapter Thirteen of the *Verification Section* (Continued)**

If there be one with perverse views, foolish obstinacy, and malevolent intent—who, upon seeing this scripture held, gives rise to all manner of hostility—with sidelong, malevolent glances, even to the point of harboring a single evil thought or uttering a single evil word, and falsely slandering those who uphold this scripture, then his guilt is profound and grave. When his life expires, he shall fall into the Great Earthly Prison, with no hope of release.

Not only is the crime of blaspheming the sacred and slandering the scripture grave. If there be one with perverse views, foolish and muddled, ensnared in delusion—who, upon seeing those who recite this scripture (for *sight* is *seeing*), harbors doubt and disbelief—then he fails to recognize that this scripture is the Dao’s true words, its laws, and its teachings. He holds it in contempt, belittles it, and in aversion, slanders and defames it. He gives rise to transgressions and rebellious deeds, casting sidelong, askew glances, taking no pleasure in seeing the scripture or those who uphold it. He lacks the steadfast, pure gaze of right observation, but instead fixes his gaze with malice, scorns and despises it, even to the point of harboring a single evil thought or uttering a single evil word, falsely slandering those who uphold this scripture.

*Slander* is both praise and defamation. To uphold the scripture and do good cannot be defamed. Yet those with perverse fixation and malice, ignorant of the karmic causes of guilt and merit, unaware of the virtue of holding this scripture, falsely give rise to slanderous, abusive words against those who uphold it. Their guilt is profound and grave.

When his life is *exhausted*—for *exhausted* means *ended*—

Falling into the Great Hell—**Avīci**—the **Uninterrupted Prison**, with no term for release. *Permanent* means *eternal*, *endless*. Through false slander of the True Dharma, the karmic roots are profound and heavy; thus, one falls into hell and finds it difficult to escape.

For **cognition** is singular. If perception is not upright, it becomes perverse. Humanity is singular; if one clings in delusion and fails to awaken, one becomes **foolish**, becomes **evil**. The heart is singular; if it gives rise to malevolent thoughts, it becomes **rebellious**. The eyes are singular; if they gaze askew, it becomes **transgression**. A single thought, though minute, is singular—if one harbors a single evil intention, it becomes the root of karmic cause. A single word, though few, is singular—if one utters a single evil speech, it becomes the origin of sin.

The **Noble One** perfects the singular virtue, praises others’ goodness, and those who uphold the scripture should be commended. Yet to falsely give rise to slander is to invite calamity upon oneself. Human life originally has no inherent karmic debt—one incurs guilt through self-inflicted transgression, and this is truly lamentable.

When life is *exhausted*—for *exhausted* means *ended*—one returns to the cycle of transformation, bound by no fixed constraint. Yet even a single instance of slandering the Dharma casts one into the Great Hell, where death itself brings no peace. How then can one escape without end?

Heaven’s heart is benevolent and loving; the **Supreme Sovereign** cherishes life, and the **Divine** is just, not drowning the people. Yet those who commit crimes with no hope of release—is this Heaven’s imprisonment? The calamity is self-made; fixed karma cannot be evaded. To eliminate one’s own karmic debt, one must rely on self-rectification. If one steadfastly pursues the utmost goodness, the karmic roots will be severed.

Alas! The punishments of hell are Heaven’s retribution; the law is impartial—no father can shield his son, nor a filial child spare his parent. The Divine is utterly just; how could it erase self-inflicted karmic consequences?

If one takes refuge in the scripture and turns toward the Dharma, sincerely repents past transgressions—just as a worldly person who surrenders in truth may be spared their crime—then one may escape.

In this mortal life, the wise and foolish differ not in essence. If one cannot speak with measured words, let one’s voice conform to the **Laws**; yet do not utter falsehoods as **evil speech**. If one cannot act without fault, let one’s body be the **Measure**; yet do not commit **evil deeds** and incur bodily karmic debt. If one cannot keep the mind free from delusion, guarding the **Ultimate Truth**, then do not give rise to malevolent intentions and incur mental karmic debt.

If one does not know the **Great Dao**, do not slander the **Way**; if one does not understand the scripture, do not contradict it; if one cannot recite and uphold it, do not slander others; if one does not comprehend the **ghostly**, **life and death**, **cause and effect**, do not give rise to destructive speech. With a single mind of upright faith, one will gradually illuminate the **One Dao**, becoming a **Sage of Truth**—what karmic guilt could then remain?
